docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: While Randi Hutter Epstein (''Questioning the 'Deadline' for Weaning,'' Sept. 21) highlights some of the reasons for extended nursing cited by the scientific community, toddler nursing isn't just about getting the child through a temper tantrum. I've experienced no better way of comforting a bruised toddler, nourishing a sick child who can't eat or helping to wake up gently and sweetly the cranky post-napper.
docs.abstract: Letter from Susan Forrester on further reasons for extended nursing, in addition to ones cited in Sept 21 article (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: What happens when a pregnant wife finds out the sex of the coming baby but asks that the doctor tell no one -- including her husband? If the husband wants to know, is the obstetrician ethically bound not to tell him at the order of his patient? Or does her husband have a right to know? /Sy Presten, New York 'It's not at all uncommon to have one parent want to know and one not,'' says Dr. Joshua A. Copel, professor of obstetrics and gynecology at Yale. But, he emphasizes, ''our medical relationship is with the woman.'' After the baby is born, the father and mother have an equal say in child raising, but before that, the father's curiosity does not supersede the mother-to-be's right to privacy, an essential part of the doctor-patient relationship. (Though some states require doctors to report certain contagious diseases, including tuberculosis and syphilis, so that medical officers can notify the patient's contacts.) So finally, the decision is hers.

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 9-26-99: The Ethicist; Pregnant Pause

docs.lead_paragraph: THREE HUNDRED SIX days, 4 hours, 5 minutes and 8 seconds left until retirement; 195 days, 15 hours, 4 minutes and 59 seconds left until the baby is due; 55 days, 11 hours, 2 minutes and 3 seconds to meet that sales quota. Time is ticking on Budd Goldman's clock. But his is not a regular watch. Time past is irrelevant. Counting down is Mr. Goldman's business, calculating the moments left until almost any occasion imaginable.
docs.abstract: Article on Budd Goldman, creator and owner of Countdown Clocks International of Mineola, Long Island; Goldman recently started line of keepsake clocks for consumers to track time until significant milestones; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal appeals court ruling against three state laws banning a late-term abortion procedure has propelled the issue toward a hearing by the Supreme Court and could complicate efforts in Congress to outlaw the procedure. On Friday, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit in St. Louis upheld lower court rulings rejecting laws in Arkansas, Iowa and Nebraska that made it a crime to perform the medical procedure that critics call partial-birth abortions.

headline.main: Abortion-Method Ruling May Spur Supreme Court

docs.abstract: Federal appeals court ruling against three state laws banning late-term abortion procedure propels issue toward hearing by Supreme Court and could complicate efforts in Congress to outlaw procedure; 30 states have passed laws banning procedure, which critics call partial-birth abortion; lower courts have struck down or stayed implementation of bans in 20 states, using same reasoning that appeals court cited in voiding such bans in Arkansas, Iowa and Nebraska; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: KAZ Peck an advocate for children with special needs, the mother of a child diagnosed with Down syndrome and a community spitfire -- fights for the underdog; she is one. At 38, her life reads like a movie-of-the-week script. It has every kind of heartbreak, moments of sheer terror and long stretches of selfless, almost superhuman perseverance. The networks would probably reject the story -- nobody would believe it's true.
docs.abstract: Profile of and interview with Kaz Peck, who worked with other parents to found New Jersey Regional Early Intervention Collaboratives, nonprofit early intervention service for children from birth to age 3; Peck, whose son, Hebert, 6, has Down syndrome, comments on her work on behalf of mainstreaming special-needs students; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An operation that appears to have restored fertility to a young woman whose ovaries had been removed has offered hope to thousands of other young women facing infertility brought on by cancer treatment or benign conditions like ovarian cysts. The procedure has also touched off speculation -- some of it farfetched, scientists say -- about whether ovarian transplants might one day be used to help women ward off menopause indefinitely and have babies well into their golden years.

headline.main: Ballerina's Ovarian Tissue Transplant Gives Hope to Other Young Women Facing Infertility

docs.abstract: Margaret Lloyd-Hart, 30-year-old ballerina, appears to have had her fertility restored after ovarian tissue that was removed from her and frozen at age 28 is reimplanted; operation may offer hope of fertility to thousands of other young women who face chemotherapy for cancer or who, like Lloyd-Hart, suffer from benign conditions like ovarian cysts; Dr Kutluk Oktay, surgeon, dismisses speculation that procedure could be used to stop menopause in older women or that it can be done for women with ovarian cancer; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Barring a dramatic last-minute intervention by the state's highest court, New Jersey will begin Sunday to enforce a law that requires girls under age 18 to notify at least one parent before being allowed to end a pregnancy. As abortion clinics and state health officials scrambled today to prepare for the new law, judges in the Appellate Division of State Superior Court denied an emergency appeal from abortion rights advocates, allowing the law to take effect as scheduled.

headline.main: New Jersey Abortion Limits Near as Court Battle Goes On

docs.abstract: New Jersey will begin Sept 26 enforcing law that requires girls under age 18 to notify at least one parent before being allowed to end pregnacy, barring dramatic last-minute intervention by state's highest court (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit rendered three crucial rulings on abortion yesterday, striking down as unconstitutional the so-called ''partial birth'' abortion statutes in Nebraska, Arkansas and Iowa. The language of the Nebraska and Iowa laws was nearly identical to definitions used in the Federal partial-birth abortion ban proposed in Congress. The court found that all three state laws placed an undue burden on abortion rights by outlawing even the procedures most commonly used prior to fetal viability. The rulings show that efforts to undermine abortion rights through the partial-birth ruse will not stand up to constitutional review. Missouri, which was not a party in the three cases but is in the Eighth Circuit and will be governed by yesterday's rulings, recently enacted an extreme anti-choice law in the guise of a partial-birth abortion ban. Gov. Mel Carnahan showed political courage in vetoing the measure, but the Legislature overrode his veto. The Eighth Circuit decision has now shown that Governor Carnahan was right.
docs.abstract: Editorial welcomes Federal appeals court rulings striking down the so-called 'partial-birth' abortion statutes in Nebraska, Arkansas and Iowa; says that while proponents say such laws are aimed at single method used in late-term abortions, they are so broad that they can be used to criminalize the most common abortion procedures performed at any point, even prior to fetal viability (M)
docs.snippet: The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit rendered three crucial rulings on abortion yesterday, striking down as unconstitutional the so-called ''partial birth'' abortion statutes in Nebraska, Arkansas and Iowa. The language of the...

docs.lead_paragraph: A Superior Court judge rebuffed yesterday a request by abortion-rights advocates to block a new law that requires doctors to get written approval from a least one parent of any girl under 18 seeking to end her pregnancy. The judge's decision denying a preliminary injunction of the parental-notification law, which is to take effect on Sunday, was hailed by anti-abortion groups as a significant step in their efforts to reverse New Jersey's tradition of abortion rights.

headline.main: Parental Approval Law On Abortion Survives Test

docs.abstract: Judge Marguerite T Simon rebuffs request by abortion-rights advocates to block New Jersey law that requires doctors to get written approval from at least one parent of any girl under 18 seeking to end her pregnancy (S)
